newsitem.title: USA: U.S. LPGs mostly bearish in light trade.
newsitem.headline: U.S. LPGs mostly bearish in light trade.

text.p: The U.S. spot liquefied petroleum gas market weakened in thin trade on Monday as last week's EIA report, which showed near-record builds in July for propane, finally took its toll, traders said.
Last Wednesday's report said July inventories increased by 7.1 billion barrels.
In Mont Belvieu, Texas, propane traded at 36.25 cents and 36.38 cents a gallon. The latter parcel was 15,000 barrels.
"Most people are hanging in there watching what the market is going to do," said one Houston trader. He said he would be "real surprised" to see anybody go up to 36.50 cents for propane.
Traders pegged propane's range at 36.00/36.50 cents, about a quarter cent below Friday.
"Prices are so low compared to the rest of the world that international players don't want to pay the freight charge for Houston LPG's," said another Houston player.
In Belvieu, ethane purity was the only other product heard done. It was done at 21.25 cents.
Belvieu butane and isobutane were pegged 0.25 and 0.50 cents below Friday's values, respectively.
In Conway, Kansas, the market was also slow. Propane was done at 35.75 cents, about 0.25 cent lower than Friday.
Conway natural gasoline and ethane sold for 46.75 and 19.25 cents, respectively, slightly down from Friday's ask prices. --Tim Gardner, New York Oil Desk +1 212 859 1632 --
